question_text: If you had $500 to invest in a local project, what kind of project would you want to support?
response_text: I'd put it toward helping another Black-owned business get started on Hamilton Avenue. We need more of our own shops there, not just passing through but actually building something.

question_text: What barriers have you or people you know faced when trying to access loans or funding?
response_text: Banks around here want perfect credit scores and three years of business history. My cousin tried to get a small loan to expand his barbershop and got denied twice even with a solid plan.

question_text: Would you participate in a community investment fund to support local Black-owned businesses?
response_text: Absolutely. That's exactly what we need. If we pool our resources together, we don't have to keep begging banks that don't want to help us anyway.

question_text: Is there anything else you'd like to share about investment and economic opportunity here?
response_text: I think about West College Hill back in the day, when Black families owned their homes. We had something real. We can build that again but we need capital that's actually accessible to us.

question_text: If you had $500 to invest in a local project, what kind of project would you want to support?
response_text: Something for the kids. Maybe a tutoring center or after-school program on West Galbraith. Our young people need somewhere positive to go and learn skills.

question_text: What barriers have you or people you know faced when trying to access loans or funding?
response_text: I tried to get a home improvement loan last year and the interest rate they quoted me was ridiculous. A friend of mine who's white got way better terms at the same bank. It's still happening.

question_text: Would you participate in a community investment fund to support local Black-owned businesses?
response_text: Yes, I would. I already try to shop at 1996 Eatery when I can. If there was a way to invest directly in places like that, count me in.

question_text: Is there anything else you'd like to share about investment and economic opportunity here?
response_text: We need financial literacy programs too. A lot of folks don't know how to navigate the system, and that's by design. Education and access have to go together.

question_text: If you had $500 to invest in a local project, what kind of project would you want to support?
response_text: Probably the facade improvement program. I've seen some storefronts on Hamilton that could use some help. Making the commercial district look better helps everyone.

question_text: What barriers have you or people you know faced when trying to access loans or funding?
response_text: Mostly paperwork and time. The applications are complicated and if you're working two jobs, who has time to gather all that documentation? It's designed to be difficult.

question_text: Would you participate in a community investment fund to support local Black-owned businesses?
response_text: I'd consider it. Would want to know more about how it's structured and who's managing it, but the concept makes sense.

question_text: Is there anything else you'd like to share about investment and economic opportunity here?
response_text: Not really. Just hope something actually changes. We've heard a lot of promises over the years.

question_text: If you had $500 to invest in a local project, what kind of project would you want to support?
response_text: A community garden or urban farm. Fresh food is expensive and not always easy to find around here. Growing our own would save money and bring people together.

question_text: What barriers have you or people you know faced when trying to access loans or funding?
response_text: Credit scores are the big one. One medical emergency or job loss can wreck your credit for years. Then you can't get approved for anything.

question_text: Would you participate in a community investment fund to support local Black-owned businesses?
response_text: For sure. I love the idea of keeping money circulating in our own community instead of watching it flow out to big corporations.

question_text: Is there anything else you'd like to share about investment and economic opportunity here?
response_text: I work in retail and a lot of us do around here. The wages are too low to save anything meaningful. Can't invest when you're barely making rent.

question_text: If you had $500 to invest in a local project, what kind of project would you want to support?
response_text: Job training program for young adults

question_text: What barriers have you or people you know faced when trying to access loans or funding?
response_text: Banks require too much collateral. No assets means no loans

question_text: Would you participate in a community investment fund to support local Black-owned businesses?
response_text: Yes definitely

question_text: Is there anything else you'd like to share about investment and economic opportunity here?
response_text: Need more info sessions about whats available

question_text: If you had $500 to invest in a local project, what kind of project would you want to support?
response_text: I'd want to support something like Real Deal Boxing Club. Programs that give young men discipline and purpose. That's an investment in our future right there.

question_text: What barriers have you or people you know faced when trying to access loans or funding?
response_text: My sister tried to start a catering business. Had the skills, had the customers lined up, but couldn't get a loan because she didn't have enough credit history. Not bad credit, just not enough.

question_text: Would you participate in a community investment fund to support local Black-owned businesses?
response_text: One hundred percent. We used to have that kind of thing in our communities. Rotating savings clubs. My grandmother talked about them. Time to bring that back.

question_text: Is there anything else you'd like to share about investment and economic opportunity here?
response_text: Just that we need to support each other. Nobody else is coming to save us. But together we have the power to change things.

question_text: If you had $500 to invest in a local project, what kind of project would you want to support?
response_text: Small business incubator space. Somewhere entrepreneurs can work without high overhead costs while they're getting started.

question_text: What barriers have you or people you know faced when trying to access loans or funding?
response_text: The process takes forever. By the time you hear back, sometimes the opportunity has passed. Speed matters when you're trying to grow a business.

question_text: Would you participate in a community investment fund to support local Black-owned businesses?
response_text: Yes, I think supporting minority-owned businesses benefits the whole community. Economic diversity makes us stronger.

question_text: Is there anything else you'd like to share about investment and economic opportunity here?
response_text: More networking events would help. Connecting business owners with each other and with potential investors.

question_text: If you had $500 to invest in a local project, what kind of project would you want to support?
response_text: Home repair assistance for seniors. A lot of elderly folks on fixed incomes can't afford to maintain their homes and end up losing them.

question_text: What barriers have you or people you know faced when trying to access loans or funding?
response_text: Age discrimination is real too. Once you're past a certain age, banks don't want to lend to you even if you've got the income and good credit.

question_text: Would you participate in a community investment fund to support local Black-owned businesses?
response_text: I would, within my means. Every little bit helps if enough people participate.

question_text: Is there anything else you'd like to share about investment and economic opportunity here?
response_text: I remember when this area was thriving. Black businesses everywhere. We can get back to that but it takes intentional effort and capital.

question_text: If you had $500 to invest in a local project, what kind of project would you want to support?
response_text: Workforce development. Help people get certifications and skills that lead to better paying jobs. That's how you break the cycle.

question_text: What barriers have you or people you know faced when trying to access loans or funding?
response_text: Man, where do I start? Bad credit from years ago that won't go away. Addresses in the wrong zip code. Being told you need a co-signer when you're a grown adult.

question_text: Would you participate in a community investment fund to support local Black-owned businesses?
response_text: Yeah, I'm in. Tired of complaining about the problem. Time to be part of the solution.

question_text: Is there anything else you'd like to share about investment and economic opportunity here?
response_text: We need more Black financial advisors and loan officers. People who understand our situation and actually want to help us succeed.

question_text: If you had $500 to invest in a local project, what kind of project would you want to support?
response_text: Childcare cooperative. Working parents need affordable options. Can't get ahead if all your money goes to daycare.

question_text: What barriers have you or people you know faced when trying to access loans or funding?
response_text: I got denied for a car loan even with a job because my debt-to-income ratio was off. Needed the car to get to the job. It's a catch-22.

question_text: Would you participate in a community investment fund to support local Black-owned businesses?
response_text: Absolutely. I try to support Twisted Nails and other local spots whenever I can. Would love a more formal way to invest.

question_text: Is there anything else you'd like to share about investment and economic opportunity here?
response_text: The $25,000 facade grants are great but we need to spread the word more. A lot of business owners don't even know about them.

question_text: If you had $500 to invest in a local project, what kind of project would you want to support?
response_text: Technology training center. Computer skills, coding basics. That's where the jobs are going and our kids need access.

question_text: What barriers have you or people you know faced when trying to access loans or funding?
response_text: Predatory lenders target our neighborhoods. People end up in worse situations because the legitimate options aren't accessible.

question_text: Would you participate in a community investment fund to support local Black-owned businesses?
response_text: Yes. It's one of the only ways to build generational wealth in our community. We have to invest in ourselves.

question_text: Is there anything else you'd like to share about investment and economic opportunity here?
response_text: Connect with Cincinnati's Black business networks. We're a small city but we're part of a larger ecosystem.

question_text: If you had $500 to invest in a local project, what kind of project would you want to support?
response_text: Mental health services. People are struggling and there's nowhere affordable to go around here. That affects everything including economic productivity.

question_text: What barriers have you or people you know faced when trying to access loans or funding?
response_text: The interest rates in this area are higher than in wealthier neighborhoods. Same bank, different rates depending on where you live.

question_text: Would you participate in a community investment fund to support local Black-owned businesses?
response_text: I think so, yes. Would need to understand the details but I support the concept.

question_text: Is there anything else you'd like to share about investment and economic opportunity here?
response_text: More transparency about where city funds go would help. People want to see their tax dollars working for them.

question_text: If you had $500 to invest in a local project, what kind of project would you want to support?
response_text: Youth entrepreneurship program

question_text: What barriers have you or people you know faced when trying to access loans or funding?
response_text: Credit history and lack of collateral

question_text: Would you participate in a community investment fund to support local Black-owned businesses?
response_text: Yes 100%

response_text: No

question_text: If you had $500 to invest in a local project, what kind of project would you want to support?
response_text: A community credit union or lending circle. Something that's owned by and accountable to the people here.

question_text: What barriers have you or people you know faced when trying to access loans or funding?
response_text: Everything requires a down payment now. Even getting approved means nothing if you can't come up with 20% upfront.

question_text: Would you participate in a community investment fund to support local Black-owned businesses?
response_text: Yes, and I already informally do this with family and church members. Would be good to have something more organized.

question_text: Is there anything else you'd like to share about investment and economic opportunity here?
response_text: The church could be a partner in this. A lot of trust and resources already exist in our congregations.

question_text: If you had $500 to invest in a local project, what kind of project would you want to support?
response_text: Honestly, I'd want to see it go toward fixing up the commercial strip. More businesses means more jobs means more money staying local.

question_text: What barriers have you or people you know faced when trying to access loans or funding?
response_text: The requirements keep changing. You meet one thing and then they want something else. Feels like they're looking for reasons to say no.

question_text: Would you participate in a community investment fund to support local Black-owned businesses?
response_text: Maybe. Depends on the return and the risk. I'm not wealthy, so I'd need to know my money is protected.

question_text: Is there anything else you'd like to share about investment and economic opportunity here?
response_text: Just that actions speak louder than words. A lot of surveys like this don't lead to anything. Hope this one's different.

question_text: If you had $500 to invest in a local project, what kind of project would you want to support?
response_text: Emergency assistance fund for families facing eviction or utility shutoffs. Prevention is cheaper than recovery.

question_text: What barriers have you or people you know faced when trying to access loans or funding?
response_text: Speaking for myself, past bankruptcy made it impossible to get credit for years. One bad period and you're marked.

question_text: Would you participate in a community investment fund to support local Black-owned businesses?
response_text: I would. We have to stop the cycle of money leaving our community and never coming back.

question_text: Is there anything else you'd like to share about investment and economic opportunity here?
response_text: Partner with Hamilton County resources. There's probably programs we don't know about that could help.

question_text: If you had $500 to invest in a local project, what kind of project would you want to support?
response_text: Grants for first-time homebuyers. Homeownership is how families build wealth over generations.

question_text: What barriers have you or people you know faced when trying to access loans or funding?
response_text: Student loan debt kills your debt-to-income ratio. Did the right thing getting educated and now can't qualify for a mortgage.

question_text: Would you participate in a community investment fund to support local Black-owned businesses?
response_text: Yes, this is something I've wanted to see for a long time. Collective economics is the way forward.

question_text: Is there anything else you'd like to share about investment and economic opportunity here?
response_text: Look at what West College Hill accomplished in the past. 77% Black homeownership by 1940. That's our blueprint.

question_text: If you had $500 to invest in a local project, what kind of project would you want to support?
response_text: Senior services. Transportation, meal delivery, home maintenance. Our elders built this community and deserve support.

question_text: What barriers have you or people you know faced when trying to access loans or funding?
response_text: Digital divide is a barrier too. A lot of applications are online now and not everyone has reliable internet or computer skills.

question_text: Would you participate in a community investment fund to support local Black-owned businesses?

response_text: Vocational training. Trades pay well and we have a shortage. Plumbing, electrical, HVAC. Real careers.
